The chair recognizes Councilor Flaherty the chair of the Committee on Public Safety Criminal Justice. Councilor Flaherty you have the floor. Thank you Mr. President. Just by way of background in 2012 Massachusetts passed its first ever post conviction DNA in forensic analysis law creating a historic opportunity for cross -agency collaboration to expand the availability of DNA testing to substantiate innocent victims in innocent claims. A coalition of leading Massachusetts criminal justice stakeholders therefore formed a working group to create the infrastructure necessary to fully realize the potential of this new law. This group established a statewide review of cases involving hair microphagy enabled state and county law enforcement departments to inventory physical evidence streamline the process for agreed -upon DNA testing in serious violent felony cases and paid for DNA testing in dozens of violent felony cases. The OGP and BGA funding awarded to the mass committee of public counsel services enables the MSP crime lab to compete its phase two of its hair review for all counties statewide expands the working group to include representatives of the Boston Police Department crime lab and the Suffolk County District Attorney's Office IRB funding an overtime funding system to defray overtime costs for evidence offices and crime lab personnel to catalog DNA evidence for post conviction cases enables the BPD crime lab to conduct the system wide review to identify all cases from 1980 to 2000 in which physical evidence is suitable for DNA testing and testing could yield information relevant to the identity identity of the perpetrator. It enables the Suffolk County District Attorney's Office IRB and the CPCS committee of public counsel service to implement a proactive data -driven approach to evaluating categories of cases identified by the working group partnership to expand staffing capacity to litigate according. It facilitates collaboration of stakeholders and working group members to efficiently locate key physical evidence in cases currently under review. It improves evidence documentation and storage and closed cases to ensure for the availability of future forensic testing and it supports ongoing efforts to disseminate and train stakeholders on best practices evidence location handling storage and also to ensure future access to forensic analysis. As folks may recall the BPD crime lab received a hundred ninety seven thousand four hundred fifty dollars and this was fifty three thousand six forty of which has recently been added through a contract amendment and it's to conduct a system -wide review to identify as mentioned cases from 1980 to 2000 and those are cases that are eligible for DNA retesting. This grant end date is September 30th of 2023 which was recently extended so somewhat time is somewhat of the essence to move these funds forward so as the chair of public safety and criminal justice like to move for suspension and passage of this fifty three thousand six hundred forty dollars to go to this very important function. Docket number 0 4 0 5, ordinance to increase the allocated budget for City Council staff. The Chair recognizes Councillor Flynn, Chair of the Committee on Rules and Administration. Councillor Flynn, you have the floor. Thank you, Councillor Brayden. The Committee on Rules and Administration held a working session on Monday, April 10th to discuss the ordinance offered by Councillor Fernandez -Anderson about the allocation for the City Council budget staff. I want to thank my colleagues for attending including Councillors Fernandez -Anderson, Councillor Murphy, Councillor Clutter, Councillor Mejia, Councillor Luigen and Councillor O 'Rourke. At the working session we discussed the recent salary levels of our City Council staff including recent increases to the budget in order to right -size our staff salary to make sure it's more competitive, retain talent and better compensate our hard -working staff. We also discussed comparative salaries from other city departments and from other cities and the cost of living in our city. We also discussed paid time off, family leave and budget for hiring when that staff member is on active duty. Councillors still have questions regarding data from historic City Council staff budget salaries for similar positions and other related data. We all agree that our staffs are indispensable, that they should earn a fair wage for all the work they do. I believe we still have work to do to come to a common ground that will allow us to offer good wages while being fiscally responsible. I also believe that Councillor Fernandez -Anderson will come back with more information as well and City Council Central staff is doing some research on some issues that came up during this hearing. At this time I do want to give City Councillor Fernandez -Anderson the opportunity to speak if that's okay. Thank you, President Flynn. Councillor Fernandez -Anderson, you have the floor. Thank you. Thank you, Councillor President Flynn for allowing me to speak on this but also for hosting or for holding the working session. Essentially, Councillor President Flynn has been a strong advocate to increase the Council staff budget in order for us to be able to actually pay people what they should be getting paid. I propose that everyone, based on cost of living, based on housing market, based on just overall credentials and the level of work here, comparing it to New York and other cities, comparing the job duties. We heard from our colleagues and as Councillor President Flynn mentioned, there were different points about whether it was a bigger office or more staff or less work and so we are looking into data to specifically figure out whether we should be increasing Council administration staff every other year and then alternating that with the Council staff as well so that the pay increase matches with the inflation and increases. So I look forward to going back to the working session and working with Councillor President Flynn. My suggestion is that everyone that works for us, that our Council staff make a minimum of $72 ,000 a year and that begins with the lower level position and then that our chief of staff have a standard so that we can actually codify it but that to leave the decision making to discretion of the Councillors in terms of measuring qualifications, looking at where people are coming in, in terms of their qualifications and experience, but that the range, and I'll just give you a couple, the range for chief of staff should go from a very minimum entry level or lesser qualifications of $72 ,000 baseline all the way up to $103 ,000 a year and that we should not be looking at comparing our salaries as City Councillors with our staff. We know that increasing our budget for our pay is contentious or it's controversial and people will come out, all the trolls and Twitter what might start saying that City Councillors are politicians and greedy and therefore wants to pay themselves a lot of money, not taking into consideration that you take home really like $75 ,000 and four of us here are single parents, but this is not about us. Again, we shouldn't compare what we get paid to our staff and our staff go above and beyond and our chief of staff most likely work between on a good day 50 hours a week and most of the time 50 to 60 to 70 hours a week And We know that. We know that they are qualified. We talked about that most of them are either attorneys or that they have high qualifications and they come in and they put in the work and they put in the heart and that we should pay them but not just because we care about them and the work but also because of the cost of living. We looked at data that showed that whatever way of paying people now, some chief of staff make $75 ,000 or I don't know, I looked at the numbers and some people are making $70 ,000 and some people are making at the most I saw was I think $80 ,000 and that's considering if you give your staff a bonus but still there's a 26 % tax on bonuses so essentially they have to pay taxes on that again later when they file their taxes so it doesn't really make a lot of sense and we're just going to keep it really plain. The point is that we're not paying our staff properly and again, I'll say it here, if we love people and we care about people, we respect them and if you respect them, you pay them. Thank you. Thank you so much, Mr. President, and thank you so much to the Councillors who joined us for this omnibus hearing on all things trash, rats and recycling. I was joined by my colleagues, many of them co -sponsors of the various dockets, so President Flynn, Councillor Lui -Jen, Councillor Braydon, Councillor Colletta and then Councillor Murphy as well. It was a really good conversation. We had Public Works represented by Dennis Roach here, Code Enforcement represented by John Blackmore and then John Ulrich from Environmental Services at ISD and just I think had a really good integrated conversation. What the committee's found over the last few years is that since rats and code enforcement needs are really the downstream results of how trash is being managed upstream at Public Works, it really makes sense to have everybody at a table talking together. There was a particular focus on the upcoming renewal of, we're in a five -year trash contract and the new RFP for the next trash contract needs to get finalized this fall. A lot of the ways in which in our neighbourhoods the trash contract isn't working ideally have kind of crystallized and part of the goal and Public Works is hiring a trash fellow to work on this but part of the council goal has really been to use this moment to make sure that we have the best system for the residents of Austin and for really improving quality of life. From my perspective, in my part of the city there's a particular focus on how to shift the dynamic in neighbourhoods where we don't have consistent containerization of trash where trash is out overnight in thin bags because it really is just like telling the rats come and get it and we know they're nocturnal and we know they can chew through two ply plastic bags so you know I think we had some really good conversation about possibly having some more tailored approaches to those parts of the city you know ideally from my perspective getting it to be that in the places where we don't have containerization trash is only going out during the day and it's just not sitting out overnight because as John Ulrich you know raised to us again and again although the ISD folks do an amazing job going out and baiting public areas the you know baiting is that downstream solution and the more that we can remove the food source from the rats the better so we also talked about the composting program and the way in which that's pulling some of the organic food that the rats most desire out of those trash bags and into a separate stream and kind of talked about the ongoing need to grow that program and make sure that the city's got the back end and to handle it So there were a lot of really good questions asked by councillors it's a big focus I think for many of us and and I think you know an area where we're really working in partnership with the departments I think you know just like we continue to pull together the different departments in these hearings I think one of the He grew up to be a 15 -year -old dedicated to pursuing his Ph .D. and one day becoming the first black president of the United States. During his life, he advocated for violence prevention, proclaiming that if true peace is to happen, it will be up to his generation, regardless of which side street they came from. Louis worked throughout his community, striving to build bridges and heal wounds. His inspiration has continued far beyond his tragic passing, carried forward by his parents, Joseph and Tina Cherry, and the Louis D. Brown Peace Institute. Here they worked tirelessly to support families and communities impacted by murder, trauma, grief and loss. Louis believed that we all have a part to play in fostering a more peaceful world through our personal and collective civic engagement. BPS has an obligation to demonstrate compliance with federal equity requirements for Title I funds for English learner students, or EL students. Boston, and especially East Boston, is home to many new arrival students and those who do not speak English as their first language. Ahead of our budget conversations where we sit here and listen to BPS presentations for what seems like days, I'd like to have access to this data to cut through the noise as it is mandated by a consent decree to ensure that we are truly serving our EL students. A little bit of details on this META consent decree. In 1992, BPS as a district and parents of EL students represented by attorneys with the Multicultural Education Training and Advocacy Project, or the META project, entered into a binding consent decree. The decree requires that Title I funds be used to benefit ELs to the same extent as other students. It commits BPS to, and I'm just going to name a few, improve and provide equal access to programs for EL students, adjust Title I school budgets for staff and services annually and periodically in light of changing student needs, meaningfully consult with and involve EL parents in each school, and more importantly, report annually on the status of Title I services to EL students. As of today, all components of this equity compliance monitoring have not taken place. The required checklists produced by individual schools were never furnished by BPS. There are three sets of documents that I'm requesting. First, a budget plan that describes the needs of EL students and how the Title I services being described will address those specific needs. Second, at the end of the school year, BPS must share Title I checklists for each school, showing how it actually spends the funds allocated in the respective schools during that year. And lastly, I'm requesting the details of the centrally directed portion of these Title I funds. These are funds that go directly to central office, and ask for details of how ELs benefited equitably from those funds as well. To summarize, the Council and the public are entitled to review these checklists before the Council is expected to review the S .Y. 24 BPS budget. This is information that has been utilized by some of our colleagues in past BPS and budget discussions, and I think it would be beneficial for all of us to have this information so that we can effectively advocate on behalf of our students. Thank you so much. Thank you, Councilor Colletta. The Chair recognizes Councilor Mejia. Councilor Mejia, you have the floor. Thank you, Mr. President, and I would like to thank Councilor Colletta for filing a request for Title I district dollars targeted to EL during school year between 2020 and 2023. Accountability is an essential part of promoting equity and being intentional about supporting Boston Public Schools students. It is not enough to state a dollar amount number without revealing how, where, when EL students are being supported to understand the full scope of the issue and how success can be achieved. This information will allow us to understand how dollars are being spent towards supporting English language learners. We look forward to analyzing this, if there are any areas of improvement in order to utilize each dollar to its fullest extent. It is essential to understand how the budget has addressed the social and educational needs of ELs. Receiving this data will ensure that we are making conscious and informed decisions regarding the $42 million in Title I for the next school year. As an English language learner myself, I think it's important, and as someone who has already filed a number of different hearings, that this is an opportunity for us to really look into the return on our investment. I do agree with Councilor Colletta. Oftentimes when we have the budget season, we come here with a lot of PowerPoint presentations and you need the Google Translate or the DaVinci Code to try to understand dollar for dollar how these investments are being had. I think this level of scrutiny in terms of data will really help us prepare. Looking forward to getting that information in a timely fashion. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Councilor Mejia. Council President Flynn, City Councilors, and guests, today April 5th is Gold Star Spouses Recognition Day, but before I recognize these spouses that are lining up behind me, I want to tell you a little bit about what the Gold Star symbol is all about. The Gold Star symbol began back during World War I when families hung banners with blue stars representing family members in service and if the service member passed, the blue star was replaced by the gold star. The term Gold Star family, Gold Star spouses, and Gold Star wives traditionally refer to surviving loved ones of military members who lost their lives in the line of duty. We, everyone in this chamber, everyone in the City of Boston, in the Commonwealth, and in this country are indebted to the men and women in our armed forces as we remember those who have died in service to our country. We must also remember the spouses and the families that are left behind who have suffered the great loss of their family member for the sake of our country. The United States Congress designated April 5th as Gold Star Spouses Day back in 2013 in recognition of the sacrifices made by the spouses and family members are fallen heroes. These spouses, they never asked to be a member of the Gold Star community, but they are and we are truly indebted to them. When our service members are overseas and they're serving our country and they don't come back, it's because of the families that are behind them, behind me, I'm sorry, as to why they will always be remembered and honored and all of us are indebted to that. I'd like to thank my Council colleagues for attending, Council President Flynn, Councilor Murphy, Councilor Flaherty, Councilor Lara, Councilor Colletta, and Councilor Lui -Jen. I'd also like to thank members of the Administration for attending, Reverend Mariama White -Hammond, Chief of Environment and Energy and Open Space, Dr. Allison Brezis, Commissioner of the Environment Department. The Specialized Stretch Code focuses on maximizing energy efficiency, reducing heating demands, and promoting efficient electrification by requiring new construction and buildings undergoing major renovations to be as energy efficient as possible. Buildings that use only electricity as an energy source versus fossil fuels can eliminate their emissions when electricity comes from renewable resources. The Specialized Municipal Opt -in Code includes net zero building performance standards and is designed to achieve state greenhouse gas emission limits and sublimits. This code helps Massachusetts meet its goal of 50 percent greenhouse gas emissions reduction from the 1990 baseline levels by 2030 and to reduce emissions gradually to net zero by 2050. During the meeting, we heard from the Administration on the process and timeline that occurred at the state level for the adoption of this code, which began in late 2018 and concluded in September of 2022. This process included passage of the Climate Act of 2021, which was signed by Governor Baker, which required the Department of Energy resources to create this code, as well as numerous public comments and public hearing sessions. As Chair of the Committee on Government Operations, I recommend passage of this committee report to ensure there is no further delay for the City to opt -in to this already existing legislation at the state level and to cement Boston as a leader in sustainability and climate resilience. April is Fair Housing Month, and it's a month that reminds us that the principle of fair housing is not only federal law, but it's also looking at what we can do here on the city and state level, and that fair housing is a fundamental right for all of us. As a City, we welcome all neighbors, recognizing the contributions and richness given by a wide variety of people from diverse backgrounds, colors, ethnicities, religious traditions, and gender identities. With this Resolution, the City of Boston commemorates the 55th anniversary of the passage of the Fair Housing Act, a landmark civil rights act that made discrimination in housing unlawful. Its passage Came only after a long and arduous journey fought by advocates around the country. Yesterday, we Recognized and remembered the 55th anniversary of the assassination of Dr. King, and it is that tragic event that really spurred our national political leaders into action when President Lyndon Johnson urged for the bill's speedy passage in Congress, and it was signed into law on April 11, 1968. Our very Own Senator Edward Brooke, the first black senator to be elected via a popular mandate, testified in the Senate about his own experience as a World War II veteran coming home and not being able to find housing of his choice because of restrictive covenants and the role that discrimination was playing in the housing market. So I Honor the legacy of all of those who came before, who fought for this, and made our political leaders do the right thing. In the City of Boston, our own laws go even further than the national requirements, adding further protections to people. The City Of Boston, our policy says we're required to see that each individual, regardless of their race, color, religious creed, marital status, military status, handicap, children, national origin, sex or gender identity or expression, age, ancestry, sexual preference or source of income, shall have equal access to housing and to encourage and bring about mutual understanding and respect among all individuals in the city by the elimination of prejudice, intolerance, bigotry and discrimination in the area of housing. We all Know that even with the passage of the Fair Housing Act, discrimination still persists, sometimes in obvious ways and sometimes in subtle ways. There's an Article this week in Boston .com talking about the further segregation in our city because of black home buyers who face discrimination or are being outbid in the housing market here. And so It's something that we must pay attention to. We discussed At our recent hearing on lending discrimination that paired testing is a gold standard of a testing methodology to ensure that we are aggressively going after those who are discriminating in our housing market. And we Need to make it very clear that the city of Boston is being aggressive in this front to let realtors, brokers and everyone know that we take housing discrimination very seriously. And so We heard from the Executive Director of the Fair Housing Commission here, Bob Terrell, about the need for us to have more testers, for us to have in -house testers, more of which we'll hear of during the budget process. So I Encourage us all to be supportive so that we can do our role in dismantling housing discrimination in our market. And I Also encourage everyone to sign up. There are Two events happening from April 11th to April 13th. There's the Virtual 17th Annual Fair Housing and Civil Rights Conference that Bob Terrell is leading. There's also CHAPA's Annual Fair Housing Symposium on April 27th from 1 to 4 p .m. exploring recent fair housing research and discussing the actions that we can take to create the future that we want to see. And I Want to thank both of those directors for being here at our hearing on lending discrimination and telling us what we need to do in order to continue to make sure that the Fair Housing Act is realized both on the federal level but what we can do here on the municipal level. So thank You. Suspension and Pass today. Thank you. Thank you, Councillor Lui -Jen. The Chair Recognizes Councillor Bach. Councillor Bach, You have the floor. April is Second Chance Month, and this morning, Rep. Montano, Rep. Orrell, and myself received a tour of the South Bay Correctional, House of Correction from Sheriff Tompkins, Superintendent Sweeney, and Jim Walz. Without Second Chances, few of us would be in this room today. We've made Mistakes, learned and done better the next time. Some of Us in this room, through our own lived experiences or hearing the experience of the communities we serve, understand that too many in our city, it feels like they didn't even have a first chance. For many Individuals reentering the communities, we promise a second chance to those whose decisions have led them to incarceration. Upon serving Their time, some are often met for the first time in their lives with the support and wraparound services they need.
